title: Overview of duke
code: plot <- ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +   geom_point(aes(color = body_mass_g)) +   labs(     title = "Bill Length vs. Bill Depth",      x = "Bill Length (mm)",      y = "Bill Depth (mm)"   )  plot +   scale_duke_continuous() +   theme_duke() plot +   geom_point(aes(shape = species)) +   scale_duke_continuous() +   theme_duke() plot +   scale_duke_continuous() +   theme_minimal()

title: Overview of duke
code: plot1 <- ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm, color = species)) +   geom_point(size = 2) +   labs(title = "Bill Length vs. Bill Depth", x = "Bill Length (mm)", y = "Bill Depth (mm)")  ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm)) +   geom_point(aes(color = species)) +   labs(     title = "Bill Length vs. Bill Depth",      subtitle = "This is the subtitle",      caption = "All text is in Duke Royal Blue",      x = "Bill Length (mm)",      y = "Bill Depth (mm)"   ) +   facet_wrap(~species) +   theme_duke() +   scale_duke_color_discrete() plot1 +   theme_duke() +   scale_duke_color_discrete() plot1 +   scale_duke_color_discrete() +   theme_minimal()

title: Overview of duke
code: plot2 <- ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species, fill = species)) +   geom_bar() +   labs(title = "Distribution of Penguin Species", x = "Species", y = "Count")  m_penguins <- penguins %>%   dplyr::filter(sex == "male")  plot2.1 <- ggplot(m_penguins, aes(x = sex, fill = sex)) +   geom_bar()  plot2.1 +   scale_duke_fill_discrete() +   theme_duke() # 8-category plot plot2.2 <- ggplot(students, aes(x = grade, fill = grade)) +   geom_bar()  plot2.2 +   scale_duke_fill_discrete() +   theme_duke() # 7-category plot plot2.3 <- students %>%   slice(-13) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = grade, fill = grade)) +   geom_bar()  plot2.3 +   scale_duke_fill_discrete() +   theme_duke() # 6-category plot plot2.4 <- students %>%   slice(-c(9, 10, 13)) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = grade, fill = grade)) +   geom_bar()  plot2.4 +   scale_duke_fill_discrete() +   theme_duke() # 5-category plot plot2.4 <- students %>%   slice(-c(9, 10, 13, 7, 18)) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = grade, fill = grade)) +   geom_bar()  plot2.4 +   scale_duke_fill_discrete() +   theme_duke() # 4-category plot plot2.5 <- students %>%   slice(-c(9, 10, 13, 7, 18, 4, 8)) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = grade, fill = grade)) +   geom_bar()  plot2.5 +   scale_duke_fill_discrete() +   theme_duke()

title: Overview of duke
code: plot3 <- ggplot2::ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g)) +   geom_histogram(ggplot2::aes(fill = species), alpha = 0.8) +   labs(title = "Distribution of Penguin Body Mass", caption = "(Colors used) \n Duke Royal Blue, Duke Navy Blue, Copper", x = "Body Mass (g)", y = "Count")  plot3 +   scale_duke_fill_discrete() +   theme_duke() #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`. plot3 +   scale_duke_fill_discrete() +   theme_minimal() #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

code: plot5 <- ggplot2::ggplot(penguins, ggplot2::aes(bill_depth_mm)) +   ggplot2::geom_density(ggplot2::aes(fill = species)) +   ggplot2::labs(title = "Density of Penguin Bill Depth", x = "Bill Depth (mm)", y = "Densiy")  plot5 +   scale_duke_fill_discrete() +   theme_duke() plot5 +   scale_duke_fill_discrete() +   theme_minimal()

title: Overview of duke
text: ## Jitter Plot - Discrete Color
code: plot6 <- ggplot2::ggplot(penguins, ggplot2::aes(year, body_mass_g)) +   ggplot2::geom_jitter(ggplot2::aes(color = species)) +   ggplot2::labs(title = "Comparison of Body Mass By Year", x = "Year", y = "Body Mass (g)")  plot6 +   scale_duke_color_discrete() +   theme_duke() plot6 +   scale_duke_color_discrete() +   theme_minimal() plot6.1 <- ggplot2::ggplot(penguins, ggplot2::aes(year, body_mass_g)) +   ggplot2::geom_jitter(ggplot2::aes(color = bill_length_mm)) +   ggplot2::labs(title = "Comparison of Body Mass By Year", x = "Year", y = "Body Mass (g)")  plot6.1 +   scale_duke_continuous() +   theme_duke() plot6.1 +   scale_duke_continuous() +   theme_minimal()

title: Overview of duke
code: yearly_avg <- penguins %>%   filter(!is.na(bill_length_mm)) %>%   group_by(island, year) %>%   summarize(island, year, mean = mean(bill_length_mm)) %>%   distinct(island, year, .keep_all = T) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'island', 'year'. You can override using #> the `.groups` argument.  lineplot <- ggplot(data = yearly_avg, aes(x = as.factor(year), y = mean, group = island)) +   geom_line(aes(color = island), linewidth = 1) +   geom_point(aes(color = island)) +   labs(title = "Average Island Bill Length(mm) Per Year", x = "Year", y = "Average Bill Length (mm)") +   theme_duke() +   scale_duke_color_discrete() lineplot # with point shape and line pattern lineplot.2 <- ggplot(data = yearly_avg, aes(x = as.factor(year), y = mean, group = island)) +   geom_line(aes(color = island, linetype = island), linewidth = 1) +   geom_point(aes(color = island, shape = island)) +   labs(title = "Average Island Bill Length(mm) Per Year", x = "Year", y = "Average Bill Length (mm)") +   theme_duke() +   scale_duke_color_discrete() lineplot.2

title: Authors and Citation
text: Aidan Gildea. Author, maintainer. Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Gildea , Çetinkaya-Rundel M (2023). duke: Creating Color-Blind Friendly Duke Color Package. https://github.com/aidangildea/duke, https://aidangildea.github.io/duke/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {duke: Creating a Color-Blind Friendly Duke Color Package},   author = {Aidan Gildea and Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel},   year = {2023},   note = {https://github.com/aidangildea/duke, https://aidangildea.github.io/duke/}, }

title: Creating a Color-Blind Friendly Duke Color Package
text: duke allows users generate visualizations Duke’s official suite colors color blind friendly way. using alongside ggplot2, can easily promote accessibility Duke community beyond.

title: Creating a Color-Blind Friendly Duke Color Package
text: can install official version duke CRAN : alternatively, can install development version GitHub:
code: # Install duke directly: install.packages("duke") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("aidangildea/duke")

title: Creating a Color-Blind Friendly Duke Color Package
text: package fully integrated ggplot2, therefore, allows customize several visualization features. Aesthetic functions theme_duke() scale_color_duke() quickly make graphs visually pleasing accessible audience. information use ggplot2, please visit GitHub repository.

title: Creating a Color-Blind Friendly Duke Color Package
text: using duke functions, can easily convert visualizations Duke official colors. Create visualizations using ggplot2 package. , pairing functions package, can convert Duke-branded colorblind-friendly versions.
code: library(ggplot2) library(duke)  plot1 <- ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width)) +   geom_point(aes(colour = Species)) +   labs(     title = "Sepal Length vs. Sepal Width",     caption = "Data sourced from iris in datasets package.",     x = "Sepal Length",      y = "Sepal Width"   )  plot2 <- ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width)) +   geom_point(aes(color = Sepal.Length)) +   labs(     title = "Sepal Length vs. Sepal Width",      caption = "Data sourced from iris in datasets package.",      x = "Sepal Length",      y = "Sepal Width"   ) plot1 +   theme_duke() +   scale_duke_color_discrete() plot2 +   theme_duke() +   scale_duke_continuous()

title: Creating a Color-Blind Friendly Duke Color Package
text: questions package use, please open issue.

text: eight-color colorblind friendly qualitative discrete palette based colors Duke branding guidelines.

code: duke_pal()

title: Duke Color Palette (Discrete) and Scales — duke_pal
text: Character vector Duke palette HEX codes.

title: Duke Color Palette (Discrete) and Scales — duke_pal
text: https://brand.duke.edu/colors/

title: Duke Color Palette (Discrete) and Scales — duke_pal
code: duke_pal() #> function (n)  #> { #>     n_values <- length(values) #>     if (n > n_values) { #>         warning("This manual palette can handle a maximum of ",  #>             n_values, " values. You have supplied ", n, ".",  #>             call. = FALSE) #>     } #>     unname(values[seq_len(n)]) #> } #> <bytecode: 0x55c8befbcd90> #> <environment: 0x55c8befbfea0> #> attr(,"max_n") #> [1] 8

title: Install Atkinson Hyperlegible — install_atkinson_hyperlegible
text: Atkinson Hyperlegible font named Braille Institute founder, J. Robert Atkinson. makes different traditional typography design focuses letterform distinction increase character recognition, ultimately improving readability. free anyone use!

title: Install Atkinson Hyperlegible — install_atkinson_hyperlegible
code: install_atkinson_hyperlegible()

title: Install Atkinson Hyperlegible — install_atkinson_hyperlegible
text: License

title: Install Garamond EB — install_eb_garamond
text: cousin Garamond 3 LT used Duke wordmark, EB Garamond clean distinguished serif font hews closely Duke legacy brand. flexible enough used headlines, subheads body text, exercise discretion using smaller font sizes.

title: Install Garamond EB — install_eb_garamond
code: install_eb_garamond()

text: Open Font License

title: Install Garamond EB — install_eb_garamond
text: Duke Brand Typography

what: Discrete scale constructor for color argument. — scale_duke_color_discrete
title: Discrete scale constructor for color argument. — scale_duke_color_discrete
text: Applies Duke branded accessible discrete color palette ggplot geometric objects using color argument. prioritizes high contrast colors aligned Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG).

title: Discrete scale constructor for color argument. — scale_duke_color_discrete
code: scale_duke_color_discrete(..., na.value = "#B5B5B5")  scale_duke_colour_discrete(..., na.value = "#B5B5B5")

title: Discrete scale constructor for color argument. — scale_duke_color_discrete
text: ... Arguments passed discrete_scale. na.value Color used NA values

title: Discrete scale constructor for color argument. — scale_duke_color_discrete
text: visualization discrete duke color scale

title: Discrete scale constructor for color argument. — scale_duke_color_discrete
text: Partial code function can attributed ggthemes.

title: Discrete scale constructor for color argument. — scale_duke_color_discrete
code: library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(palmerpenguins)  # default ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species)) +   geom_point() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).   # vs. with Duke scale ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species)) +   geom_point() +   scale_duke_color_discrete() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).   # vs. with shape and Duke scale ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, shape = species, color = species)) +   geom_point() +   scale_duke_color_discrete() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).   # vs. with Duke scale, UK spelling ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, colour = species)) +   geom_point() +   scale_duke_colour_discrete() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).   # Make some species NAs to demonstrate na.value usage penguins_with_NAs <- penguins |>   mutate(species = if_else(species == "Gentoo", NA, species))  # with default na.value ggplot(penguins_with_NAs, aes(x = body_mass_g, color = species)) +   geom_density() +   scale_duke_color_discrete() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_density()`).   # with custom na.value ggplot(penguins_with_NAs, aes(x = body_mass_g, color = species)) +   geom_density() +   scale_duke_color_discrete(na.value = "pink") #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_density()`).

title: Continuous scale constructor. — scale_duke_continuous
text: Applies Duke branded accessible continuous color scale ggplot geometric objects. applicable fill color arguments. Defines gradient scale dark light improve visibility contrast readers.

title: Continuous scale constructor. — scale_duke_continuous
code: scale_duke_continuous(   ...,   low = "#00539B",   high = "#E2E6ED",   space = "Lab",   na.value = "#666666",   guide = "colourbar",   aesthetics = c("colour", "color", "fill") )

title: Continuous scale constructor. — scale_duke_continuous
text: ... Arguments passed continuous_scale. low Low end color gradient. high High end color gradient. space Color space calculate gradient. na.value Color used NA values. guide Type legend. "colorbar" continuous scale, "legend" discrete scale. aesthetics String vector strings detailing aesthetic features continuous scale can apply .

title: Continuous scale constructor. — scale_duke_continuous
text: visualization continuous duke color scale

title: Continuous scale constructor. — scale_duke_continuous
code: library(ggplot2) library(palmerpenguins)  # default ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = body_mass_g)) +   geom_point() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).   # vs. with Duke scale ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = body_mass_g)) +   geom_point() +   scale_duke_continuous() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).

text: visualization discrete duke color scale fill

title: Discrete scale constructor for fill argument. — scale_duke_fill_discrete
code: library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) library(palmerpenguins)  # default ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species, fill = species)) +   geom_bar()   # vs. with Duke scale ggplot(penguins, aes(x = species, fill = species)) +   geom_bar() +   scale_duke_fill_discrete()   # Make some species NAs to demonstrate na.value usage penguins_with_NAs <- penguins |>   mutate(species = if_else(species == "Gentoo", NA, species))  # with default na.value ggplot(penguins_with_NAs, aes(x = species, fill = species)) +   geom_bar() +   scale_duke_fill_discrete()   # with custom na.value ggplot(penguins_with_NAs, aes(x = species, fill = species)) +   geom_bar() +   scale_duke_fill_discrete(na.value = "pink")

title: Implements theme components. — theme_duke
text: Defines overall aesthetic thematic features plot. function specifies simple background, grid line, text, legend arguments create minimalist design. use intended ggplot objects.

title: Implements theme components. — theme_duke
code: theme_duke(   base_size = 11,   base_family = "",   base_line_size = base_size/22,   base_rect_size = base_size/22 )

title: Implements theme components. — theme_duke
text: base_size base size base_family base family, AtkinsonHyperlegible default. base_line_size baseline size base_rect_size base rect

title: Implements theme components. — theme_duke
text: plot Duke colors

title: Implements theme components. — theme_duke
text: theme aims use Atkinson Hyperlegible font text plots default. font focuses letterform distinction increase character recognition, ultimately improving readability. Currently, font used installed user's system. , message printed directing users font can downloaded font used plots default "sans". base_family can also set "EB Garamond", recommended Duke serif font. installed user's system, font can used plots theme_duke(base_family = "EB Garamond"). , message printed directing users font can downloaded font used plots default "serif".

title: Implements theme components. — theme_duke
code: library(ggplot2) library(palmerpenguins)  # default p <- ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_depth_mm, y = bill_length_mm, color = species)) +   geom_point() +   labs(     title = "Bill length and depth of penguins",     subtitle = "Dimensions for Adelie, Chinstrap, and Gentoo Penguins",     x = "Bill depth (mm)",     y = "Bill length (mm)",     color = "Species",     caption = "Source: palmerpenguins package."   ) p #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).   # vs. with Duke theme p +   theme_duke() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).   # vs. with Duke theme and scale p +   scale_duke_color_discrete() +   theme_duke() #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).   # with Duke theme, scale, and further customization to theme p +   scale_duke_color_discrete() +   theme_duke() +   theme(     plot.title = element_text(color = "red", size = 20),     plot.background = element_rect(fill = "pink", color = "yellow"),     panel.grid = element_blank()   ) #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (`geom_point()`).
